reviewText: This is a lovely, variegated,classic rock/folk album of performances by luminaries before a live audience. While the recording strategy is variable, it's generally just fine. I cannot single out cuts which excel or fail to satify, as much as I can assure the listener that the WHOLE will do the trick.  The fact that these concerts benefit a critical non-profit organization is a perk, I suppose.The line-up is above as is the set list.  I do not intend to sell this album to anyone, only to say that if you love two or three of the performers or composers here, you will simply not be sorry.Reprise has done a superlative job of remastering these recordings, some well-aged.  The sequence of selections is sensitive ad expert; and throughout, we feel Neil Young's wonderful presence -- as well as participation.Few brick-and-mortar albums are worth the price these days. The gamble is well-on. But this purchase is a steal.  The rock-drivers of three generations are here, and they each -- with few exceptions -- deliver beautifully.Considering the junk that the industry panders as new music these days (and yes, there are exceptions)  this album is a must.
summary: Never heard a Bridge School Recording, but this one scored.
Title: The Bridge School Concerts

reviewText: Garbage.Video - 4:3 (concert disks)Audio - 2.0 PCMLot's of old clips from the 80's and 90's. You can imagine the quality transfer from those old video tapes. These 'clip's are like what you see on late night TV. The value for today's market is zero.Made it through Pearl Jam (2010) still 4:3 and 2.0 PCM - this title sucks.
Title: The Bridge School Concerts

reviewText: I've seen on video and heard some of the performances from this yearly event---once in a lifetime performances by artists you would never think of pairing up.  $26.99--you've got to be kidding me.  The idea of the radio stations giving them away as prizes is a great one.  However, something tells me there would be too many people wanting to get their hands in the pot.  I mean look at Live Aid and The Concert For Bangledesh.  All that money and almost zero got to the people who needed it.  Times have changed and I hope we've learned.  I'm confident the people involved in this will make sure the money from the sale of this through Amazon and other retailers will get where it's supposed to go.I think the thing to do is everyone who is purchasing a copy for themselves, purchase two and give one to a brother, sister, or friend and introduce them to this more than worthy cause.  Who knows, stranger things have worked.
Title: The Bridge School Concerts

reviewText: I knew that Neil Young did some benefit concerts for some kind of school, but I had no idea what that entailed until I received this as a gift and watched it.  This is an absolutely beautiful project that he helps fund.  The interview disc alone is enough for a 5 star rating.  The concert footage from over the years is just an added bonus.  If the Bridge School put out a DVD set every year of their concerts, I would buy it.  My only want is that more acts were included in this DVD set.  Highly recommended and for a great cause.
Title: The Bridge School Concerts

reviewText: I thought the 1997 Bridge School concert album was very, very good.  This two CD set is even better!You get:Disc 1:1. Born in the U.S.A. - Bruce Springsteen2. Too Much - Dave Matthews Band3. Magic's in the Makeup - No Doubt4. Gone - Jack Johnson5. Blue Ridge Mountains - Fleet Foxes6. Love and Only Love - Neil Young & Crazy Horse7. Rain on Tin - Sonic Youth8. Better Man - Pearl Jam9. The Way it Will Be - Gillian Welch10. Country Feedback - R.E.M & Neil Young11. The Great Divide - Willie Nelson12. Cry Just a Little - Nils LofgrenDisc 2:1. Elsewhere - Sarah McLachlan2. Get Back - Paul McCartney3. A Dream Come True - Elton John & Leon Russell4. Marry Song - Band of Horses5. Disposable Heroes - Metallica6. After The Gold Rush - Thom Yorke (of Radiohead)7. The Difficult Kind - Sheryl Crow8. Maybe This Time - Tony Bennett9. Déjà Vu - Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young10. Jesus, Etc. - Norah Jones11. I was Dancing in the Lesbian Bar - Jonathan Richman (of the Modern Lovers & There's Something About Mary12. Surfin' USA - Brian Wilson (of the Beach Boys13. Won't Get Fooled Again - the WhoSpringsteen, McCartney, the Who, Tony Bennett, No Doubt, Pearl Jam, Neil Young (with Crazy Horse and CSNY and REM), Brian Wilson, Jonathan Richman - all great performances!  Norah Jones, Sheryl Crow, and Sarah McLachlan are outstanding as well.  An excellent collection of excellent acoustic performances.  A definite keeper.If you're unfamiliar with it, the Bridge School Concerts are an annual event set up by Neil Young and his wife to help pay for the programs at the non-profit Bridge School, which helps children with severe speech & physical impairments.Do yourself (and the kids) a favor.  Pick this up today!
Title: The Bridge School Concerts

reviewText: Visually the early performances are a great look back into the era of long/big hair, untrimmed beards, bandanas, tie-dyed t-shirts and the protest folk-rock culture. Many of the performances could have been from Woodstock, except instead of drugged out free-loving hippies we have adults of all ages, many with severely handicapped children and similarly afflicted adults as well. So far it makes sense as these are Benefit concerts. Trouble is, the majority of the music has a definite sad and bitter edge to it as if the musicians are "depressed" by their surroundings or are "protesting" the afflictions they're there to support rather than a celebration of Life, Support and HOPE. There are exceptions, such as David Bowie and surprisingly Patty Smith, and many others. I don't regret buying it for the option of playing "selected" performances from these days-gone-by artists but couldn't watch the entire thing without visions of Doctor Kevorkian.
Title: The Bridge School Concerts
